Hmmm... I don't think french is that tricky, except maybe for pronunciation, but there's worse.
I think the trickiest thing could be "les liaisons". It's only used when speaking but basically in some cases, the last letter of a word is pronounced in a sentence when it wouldn't be if you just said the word on its own. Ex: j'ai beaucoup aim (say the p) vs. il a beaucoup d'amis (don't say the p).
It's usually the last letter of a word if it comes right before a word that starts with a vowel. It's not that complicated but quite hard to do naturally.

Hey there. How come you didn't find any information regarding visas? Here's what I found.
[https://www.talentscotland.com/work/working/visa-and-immigration/how-do-i-work-in-scotland-non-eea](https://www.talentscotland.com/work/working/visa-and-immigration/how-do-i-work-in-scotland-non-eea)
Since you're a US national, the only possible visa you can apply for is a student visa. The other visas are not applicable to you. I suppose you don't have a grandparent of British citizenship since you didn't mention it.
[https://www.scotland.org/study](https://www.scotland.org/study)
Here is some info regarding studying at a Scottish university. The rest is up to you. I hope you find what you're looking for. Good luck.

Hey you mentioned you're a law student. Why don't you try striking up a conversation with girls at the start of lectures or during contact hours. Just start with the thing you have in common (law studies) and go with the flow. Don't try to seem desperate or too pushy and don't talk to them with the only goal of sleeping with them. First and foremost, try to make friends with them.
And please don't say you've tried and they've answered with one words. That just shows you haven't tried hard enough. Also talk to your friends, ask them for honest opinions, what they think of you and what you could do better.
Also pleeeease stop obsessing over this. Believe me it's not the most important thing in the world. Also don't believe those dating gurus on youtube because they don't have the best advice.
You'll eventually get a date, don't despair.

I can only provide limited information because I don't actually work there but my parents do so it's mostly from their experience.
Cost of life is generally the same in regards to food, clothes. The only drastic increase will be for alcohol and accommodation. The average price per m2 is around 1500 and the space is limited. I don't know your finances but expect to be living in an apartment. Having a car is also quite expensive.
I checked on the foreign ministry website and you and your wife will not need a visa (don't think the skin colour will have any effect if you were worried). The procedure of becoming a resident is quite lengthy and you'll need a lot of paperwork.
For pets, I think most condos accept cats and dogs in apartment, I've seen plenty when I was there but that would depend on the landlord also.
Regarding salaries, didn't your colleague give you an approximate of what you could expect ? I'd generally expect an increase in salary because the rent can be quite high. The tax rate is lower but there's no such thing as a retirement plan so you'll need to put that aside I think. And normally your future employer should provide healthcare to you and your wife (or hers if she'll also be working).
For more detailed information I suggest you ask your colleague or possible employer as I don't really know what your salary could be. It depends on the employer. Good luck.

It's illegal but it's not really well enforced. There is this guy that decorated his house with all sorts of Nazi symbols and they asked him to take them down but they never really did anything. I think he only took them down himself recently but it still took five years or something.

From the start it was so clear they would be extending the deadline. Two years is a ridiculously short amount of time for leaving an institution which they have been a part of for more than 40 years.
Also taking into account the indecisiveness of their Parliament and the reluctance of the EU to grant a deal without making sure the Good Friday agreement is upheld, it was almost certain that they would extend the time.
As for if the UK is going to leave, I think they still are but they won't totally be independent as they wanted to before. I think maybe they'll end up with a Norway-type deal or something. At this point nobody knows.

In a mocha pot the water boils and then becomes steam. The pressure from the steam makes the water go up the tube, through the coffee and into the top part of the pot. If you do that with milk you'll just get burnt milk. Don't do it. Also don't try to heat up milk in a kettle.

I'd advise KUL. The university of Luxembourg is quite young and good but KUL has a better rep. Also, Luxembourg is very expensive for renting and I generally think you'll have a better student life in Leuven.
However, I haven't been to either uni, I'm only basing my advice on the echoes I have from students and from living in both of those countries. If you're more set on one programme than the other CHOOSE THAT ONE. Only take my advice if you're torn 50-50. Good luck
Edit: also depends if you wish to stay in the country you've studied in after your degree to find a job. Based on that my answer may change
